answers.answer: Hi,I understand your concern regarding your results. Hematuria can be caused by a variety of issues such as infection, inflammation of the kidney, urethra, bladder, or prostate as well as blood issues. ON the other hand, proteinuria, a sign of chronic kidney disease (CKD) may  result from diabetes, high blood pressure, and diseases that cause inflammation in the kidneys.. Since hematuria was first observed, this could be one factor in the finding protein in the urine at present. It is best that you discuss this also with your attending physician for proper evaluation. Factors such as your medical history, symptoms present and results of other laboratory tests are important considerations also. Additional diagnostic tests may need to be done to determine the underlying cause. Take care and do keep us posted.

Helppppp.

question: For the last 7 months I have been experiencing gross hematuria.  After several ct scans,  two cystoscopies, and endless blood test the reason of the gross hematuria is still unknown.  Around two months ago I started seeing a nephrologist to see if the blood is coming from the kidneys, and  around the same time my UA test started showing protein in my urine.  Bellow are the results of my last UA  and a 24hr urine protein.  With this results, Is the protein in my urine secondary to the gross hematuria or am I having protein in my urine because some how my kidneys are not working right???Any help will be really appreciated.Color	  Brown		 	AClarity	Turbid		 	AGlucose, Urine	NegativeBilirubin, Urine	1+		 	AUnable to confirm result due to reagent backorder.Ketones, Urine	NegativeSpecific Gravity, Ur	1.020	1.005 - 1.045Hemoglobin/Blood,Ur	3+	NEGAT	 	ApH, Urine	5.5	4.5 - 8.0Protein, Urine	100		mg/dL	AUrobilinogen	Normal	NLNitrites	Negative	NEGATLeukest	Negative	NEGATBilirubin, Ictotest	Unable to assay.
